DOC.HEAD: Living Donor Recipient Has Follow-up Operation
DOC.TEXT: The nation's second recipient of a liver from a living donor underwent another operation Tuesday to remove a pocket of infection from her abdomen, officials at the University of Chicago Hospitals said. Sarina Jones, a 16-month-old liver defect victim from Millington, Tenn., received part of a liver Dec. 8 from her father, Robert Jones, a dry-wall installer. Hospital spokeswoman Susan Phillips said Dr. Jean Emond, a member of the original transplant team, decided the best way to deal with the small abcess was to reopen the operation incision to drain and clear the area of infection. ``She tolerated the procedure very well, and was out of the operating room in about two hours,'' said Ms. Phillips, adding the infection had not been life-threatening. The spokeswoman said Sarina was listed in critical but stable condition after the two-hour operation, and was expected to be transferred out of the intensive care ward within several days. Also Tuesday, Alyssa Smith, who preceded Sarina as the nation's first living-donor liver transplant recipient, had her condition upgraded to serious. ``She continues to progress well,'' Ms. Phillips said. Alyssa was given a ``day pass'' from the hospital to visit with her parents on Christmas Day at a Ronald McDonald House for relatives of ailing children. Teresa Smith, 29, an elementary school teacher who donated part of her liver to her daughter for the Nov. 27 transplant, was released from the hospital two weeks ago. The Smiths are from Schertz, Texas. Alyssa is expected to leave the hospital sometime after the first of the year if all continues to go well, according to Ms. Phillips. Sarina and Alyssa suffer from biliary atresia, a usually fatal congenital defect which is the leading cause of liver transplants in children.
